title: Citra crashes when opening the Mii selector applet a second time in MSVS builds
body:
This is one of the weirdest issues I've ever experienced.
I only found it, cause I got unexplainable crashes when testing my WIP HLE Mii selector applet implementation.

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Use LLE Mii selector applet (or HLE but I haven't PRed it yet)
2. Compile MSVS build from master
3. Open game, do anything that opens the Mii selector applet
4. Stop the game
5. Start any game again
6. Open Mii selector applet again
7. Citra crashes

The crash happens in both Release and Debug builds.
I wasn't able to reproduce this in the Mingw Canary builds.

Log: https://pastebin.com/Yvu1XAiA
Call stack:
![unbenannt](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20753089/52534917-fd78ef80-2d47-11e9-878d-2de3f6699759.PNG)

When testing the HLE applet, it can be observed, that the second time, when it crashes `capture_info.size` is 0. 

For LLE mii applet, the size parameter in SVC::CreateMemoryBlock from the callstack is also 0 on the second run.

HLE software keyboard doesn't seem to be affected by this.

title: [Feature Request] Custom background
body:
The possibility of defining a custom background for people who make gameplay, or simply for those who want to make their emulator more personal.

In the same way that you choose the background color, add an option to search inside the PC or a folder inside the citra folder (for example "Themes" or "Backgrounds").

Nothing too fancy, by this I mean that there should be no complicated option to fit the image (unless you want to add it), but that the image is shown in the background, the person then could enlarge or shrink the emulator window to make it fit, or that the image is molded to the size of the window (stretch or shrink).

Something like this:
![screenshot_20190204_133032](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45115804/52222930-69a8ae80-2883-11e9-8732-54574a379343.png)
![screenshot_20190204_131118](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45115804/52221861-e423ff00-2880-11e9-8d80-00d625872726.png)
Sorry for my poor handling of Gimp.

title: [Feature Request] Change arrows by scroll bar
body:
All options that are handled with percentages (3D, speed limit, play coins) should have a scroll bar to handle it, as this is easier to use and faster to set, instead of arrows to raise / lower percentage.
It is a very visual request, but it would give a greater uniformity to the emulator, since some options use the arrows and others the scroll.
Also you could change all to arrows, although personally I prefer the scroll. The main idea as I said is to make the emulator more uniform and handle all options equally.

title: [Feature Request] Scroll bar and shortcut to activate or modify 3D
body: Add a Hotkey to enable/disable 3D. Besides a scroll bar (for example in the status bar) and Hotkey to change the 3D percentage. Having the 3D activated (in the monitor/TV) it is a nuisance to open the options dialog boxes (or disable and re-enable the 3D in the TV/Monitor) to modify the percentages, or enable or disable the 3D. This would make it much easier for the user to handle the 3D of the emulator.

title: [Feature Request] Show installed update and DLC
body:
Since some games don't show the update in their image, it would be good to show it in the games list, just like the DLCs installed (as yuzu does). 
To my understanding is more practical, in my case, I dump all my games, but the updates at that time gave me an error, so I understand was by the homebrew application I used for dump, and now I do not remember well which one I installed an update or DLC, it would be good to have it in sight to know if it is updated, and if you have the latest update.

title: Logging - Message Queue Size Unbounded
body:
When opening the non-executable partitions of a game such as the manual, Citra produces a lot of unmapped Read and Write error messages and rightly so.

However, this is a _lot_ of error messages, so much so that it fills the logging queue faster than any logging backend could ever hope to drain it. As I tracked down with valgrind/massif, the logging message queue is filled until it can no longer allocate memory.

A maximum size should be enforced on the logging message queue to prevent this, dropping entries written after the cap, perhaps with a log message noting that the log queue is filled and some entries have been dropped.

title: Building on FreeBSD/powerpc64 fails
body:
<!---

Please read the FAQ:
https://citra-emu.org/wiki/faq/

THIS IS NOT A SUPPORT FORUM, FOR SUPPORT GO TO:
https://community.citra-emu.org/

If the FAQ does not answer your question, please go to:
https://community.citra-emu.org/

====================================================

When submitting an issue, please check the following:

- You have read the above.
- You have provided the version (commit hash) of Citra you are using.
- You have provided sufficient detail for the issue to be reproduced.
- You have provided system specs (if relevant).
- Please also provide:
  - For crashes, a backtrace.
  - For graphical issues, comparison screenshots with real hardware.
  - For emulation inaccuracies, a test-case (if able).

--->

I'm compiling Citra on FreeBSD for powerpc64 architecture (big-endian). The error I have:
```
/usr/local/bin/g++8  -DARCHITECTURE_GENERIC=1 -DBOOST_DATE_TIME_NO_LIB -DBOOST_ERROR_CODE_HEADER_ONLY -DBOOST_REGEX_NO_LIB -DBOOST_SYSTEM_NO_LIB -DENABLE_WEB_SERVICE -DNDEBUG -DSINGLETHREADED -I/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/. -I/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/externals/fmt/include -I/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/externals/./microprofile -I/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/externals/cryptopp/. -I/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/externals/open_source_archives/include -isystem /usr/local/include -O2      -DLIBICONV_PLUG        -DLIBICONV_PLUG   -DLIBICONV_PLUG -Wl,-rpath=/usr/local/lib/gcc8 -DLIBICONV_PLUG -Wl,-rpath=/usr/local/lib/gcc8 -isystem /usr/local/include -DCRYPTOPP_ALTIVEC_AVAILABLE -maltivec -mcrypto -mvsx -Wno-attributes -O2      -DLIBICONV_PLUG        -DLIBICONV_PLUG   -DLIBICONV_PLUG -Wl,-rpath=/usr/local/lib/gcc8 -DLIBICONV_PLUG -Wl,-rpath=/usr/local/lib/gcc8 -isystem /usr/local/include -DCRYPTOPP_ALTIVEC_AVAILABLE -maltivec -mcrypto -mvsx   -std=gnu++17 -MD -MT src/core/CMakeFiles/core.dir/hle/applets/applet.cpp.o -MF src/core/CMakeFiles/core.dir/hle/applets/applet.cpp.o.d -o src/core/CMakeFiles/core.dir/hle/applets/applet.cpp.o -c /usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/core/hle/applets/applet.cpp
In file included from /usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/./core/hle/service/fs/archive.h:13,
                 from /usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/./core/hle/service/apt/applet_manager.h:12,
                 from /usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/./core/hle/applets/applet.h:9,
                 from /usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/core/hle/applets/applet.cpp:13:
/usr/local/poudriere/ports/default/emulators/citra/work/citra-4f23d5d69/src/./core/file_sys/archive_backend.h:73:15: error: static assertion failed: ArchiveFormatInfo is not POD
 static_assert(std::is_pod<ArchiveFormatInfo>::value, "ArchiveFormatInfo is not POD");
               ^~~
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

It looks like the check fails because of byte-swapping done in src/common/swap.h:682.

Other projects, like OpenRCT2 do byte-swapping on their own (OpenRCT2 actually has a patch ready to commit, to fix endianness isues), which probably would fix this issue (example at https://github.com/OpenRCT2/OpenRCT2/blob/8c6604721192ec731e9beeb57b227755530fd3ea/src/openrct2/util/Endian.h ).

Could Citra adopt a similar approach?

title: Project Mirai 2 - Gameplay/audio desync issue
body:
This game experiences audio, synchronization drift of the background music and the rest of game likely similar to #4527 and #4169.
Happens on latest Citra Canary [#1154](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra-canary/releases/tag/canary-1154) and Citra Nightly [#1169](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra-nightly/releases/tag/nightly-1169).

To verify and roughly measure desync, I wrote a file-output audio sink backend to record game audio without having to worry about emulation speed or stuttering. I then played the game based on visuals alone and listened to the results afterwards.

- When using HLE audio, at the start of a ~3 minute song, the background music was 100-200ms ahead of the rest of the game
- When using LLE audio on the same song, the background music was 400ms+ behind the rest of the game

The audio sink type and other settings (including JIT) do not seem to matter regarding synchronization.

Unlike #4527, there is no warning in the Citra log about syscore being unimplemented.

System specifications:

- CPU: Intel Core i7-7700k
- GPU: GTX 1080 Ti
- RAM: 32GB DDR4 3200MHz
- OS: Ubuntu Mate 18.04

Log file:
[citra_log_nojit.txt](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra/files/2742261/citra_log_nojit.txt)

title: Joker codes cannot be nested inside conditional statements, but the other way around works properly
body:
I thought the issue I was having was caused by something else, but I have fully determined that the issue is that, while conditional codes can be nested inside joker codes, the other way around does not work properly. Here is an example:

Does **NOT** work:
```
5803775C E1A00003 // if value is equal
08037768 E17C0173 // write disabled value
DD000000 00000102 // if R+B               -- these lines
08037768 117C0173 //  write enabled value -- are
D0000000 00000000 // endif                -- ignored
D0000000 00000000 // endif

```
Works perfectly:
```
5803775C E1A00003 // if value is equal
08037768 E17C0173 // write disabled value 
*D0000000 00000000 // endif
DD000000 00000102 // If R+B
*5803775C E1A00003 // if value is equal
08037768 117C0173 // write enabled value
D0000000 00000000 // endif
D0000000 00000000 // endif
```

Lines preceded by * are newly added.

The code "(Hold START and Open OPTIONS menu)Access the PC from anywhere" works fine, as it doesn't require pressing a direction on the circle pad.

title: [Feature Request] Hybrid Screen
body:
Hi developers.

One disadvantages when playing DS or 3DS in laptop is because laptop use landscape view while the combination of two 3DS screen will resulting portrait view. It leaves many wasted black screen in laptop which give impression that the screen looks small.

One of the nice features from DeSmuME Core in RetroArch is Hybrid Screen. It use unused screen area to show the entire DS Screen, so user can see the whole DS experience while enjoying bigger resolution for one of its screen. The Hybrid Screen can be illustrated as this:

![desmume 360x](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4508389/41812537-e1561f58-774e-11e8-9d46-ffeb07abebfd.png)

This hybrid method will have at least 3 advantages:
1. We can see the full experience of 3DS screen while enjoying bigger screen preview,
2. It looks symmetrical that give impression that the entire laptop screen has filled with game display.
3. The zoomed screen can be swapped by hotkeys.

title: Feature request: Discord chat integration
body:
Hey everyone! I don't have an issue at the moment, but I do have a request for a feature in Citra that would be really helpful.

It would be really nice if you could integrate Discord into Citra so people could Discord chat with whoever they're playing with, without having to get each other's usernames. Maybe the way it would work is people would enter their Discord username into Citra when first installing it, and then whenever they join a room, they could choose to get either text or voice chat or both before the join process starts. Or maybe instead of entering your Discord username manually, it would sync with the Discord app.

Thanks in advance.

Also support for redirecting code.bin and exheader.bin would make the life of modders way simpler.

title: [Request] Bind controls based on controller slot rather than the controller itself.
body:
In most emulators, the controls for Xinput are bound to the slot. For example, if I set up the controls for an Xbox controller, Dolphin, PCSX2, RPCS3, Cemu etc would see that as Xinput0 rather than the controller itself. I could then disconnect the Xbox controller and connect any other Xinput controller and as long as it is in slot 0 (Player 1) it will work.
In citra it seems to bind the controls per controller, that is once I set up an Xbox controller, another Xinput device cannot be used unless I rebind the controls again.

The reason this is a problem for me is because I prefer certain controllers for certain games. Xbox One for comfort, DS4 for motion controls and touch, SN30 Pro for side scrollers. All of these can use Xinput, and by binding input to the controller slot, emulators will automatically work with any of them without any configuration required.

title: Save States
body: Could we get the ability to take a snapshot of our gameplay and then be able to reload our gameplay from that snapshot (without actual saving)? For instance, let's say you're in the middle of a boss fight. The boss is at 50% health. With save states, you could save that state and go back to that point with the boss having 50% health at any time.

title: [Request] Cheat Creator/Memory Viewer
body: Emulators that are out for the Nintendo DS (Demume, NO$GBA) include a memory viewer and a built-in code maker. In order to create cheats with this program as of right now, people have to have a code that was already made for the game, along with using Cheat Engine, to guesstimate the real 3DS address of a value. This could lead to people making codes that don't work or only work half of the time or just overcomplicate the process. I'd really enjoy such a feature and would be willing to test it out. Though, I really only know how to work with base addresses/searching at the moment, so my testing ability might be limited.

title: Feature request: GPU selection in Graphics settings
body:
In systems with multiple GPU devices and monitors plugged to more than a GPU, it would be great to choose which GPU is used by Citra.

Windows 10 does have an integrated setting for it (_Display > Graphics Settings > Graphics performance preference_), but it seems that Citra isn't taking it into account.

Instead of that, the emulator simply uses whichever GPU "main" monitor is plugged into (that can be changed from Windows 10 _Display settings > Multiple displays > [x] Make this my main screen_).

What this means is that if you want to run Citra on your external GPU, you have to set the screen attached to that GPU as your main screen, _before_ running Citra. While Citra is open, it's possible to change it back because the program will keep using the GPU it has been opened on.

My request is a parameter in Citra's Graphics settings to choose between available GPU devices. That would be used whenever Citra is running, independently from Windows desktop configuration.

- I remember exactly the same behavior in ppsspp about 4-5 years ago, when Tekken 6 firstly became playable. Someone of devs who was working at that time fixed it and shared some news about - calling it a memory leakage that was very hard to find. [Already tried to google it. Extra2:
- a game is already wonderful to play. Compared to known Tekken 6 it brings adjusted AI, and firstly in a Tekken series forces a player to train in survival modes under different rules like reduced hp, or only juggle damage. It's Ultra Hard AI, new music, new stages, recreated models, different lighting system, low-polygon style combines all of this in a unique 3ds way

And that is why every citra player will experience slowdowns. There is a lot of 40-battles survival modes, which player will try again & again to accomplish. Also there is 100-battles survival mode which might also lead with game progress to a new one 100-battle survival mode, and a new one.

Right now everything is perfect for 10-stages quick battle [4-5 times] or with combining it with 10-stages survival mode. In case of any long survival 40-battles survival mode it's better firstly to restart an emu.

Extra3:
- after some time will test it in Ubuntu. It's very interesting to know how linux Mesa drivers will behave on specified old hardware.

title: [Request] Allow non-real-time "rendering" of CTM movies
body:
Currently, if you want to record Citra gameplay for a YouTube video or the like, you need to use a screen recorder or similar solution that grabs exactly what you see on your computer screen. This includes any framerate stuttering / audio slowdowns and the like that can occur even on powerful gaming PCs.

Given that Citra can now record and play back gameplay in the form of TAS "movies," and that Citra has always been able to emulate at less-than-realtime speeds, a new approach to producing gameplay video may be possible: record gameplay to a CTM file, suffering whatever random stutters/slowdowns come up, and then once the recording is complete, let Citra chew on it for a while and churn out a perfectly smooth video file.

Non-real-time rendering allows for the final video to be better [than a screen recording] in other respects, too: it can be a higher resolution than the PC comfortably supports, it can use accurate software shaders for everything, etc. The rendering can even take place on a system different from the one on which the gameplay was originally recorded.

Presumably, an initial implementation of this feature would produce a straight uncompressed video file, which would be enormous, and only good for passing in to a video encoder like FFmpeg/Handbrake/etc. to get it to a reasonable (YouTube-uploadable) size. A later iteration could do some sort of integration with such tools so that Citra hands off only a few frames at a time, reducing the disk space overhead required.

title: Citra instantly closes/crashes with some controllers/adapters connected to the PC
body:
I was asked to report that issue although I couldn't observe it myself due to the lack of a problematic controller:

Due to the changes added to support controller hotplugging Citra opens a connection to all connected controllers on startup. Some controllers (mainly some mayflash adapters) cause a crash inside SDL. This will result in an instant crash of citra without any log.

The solution to this issue for now is to unplug the controller/adapter. The controller wouldn't work for Citra anyway.

Further investigation why SDL causes the crash is necessary. E.g. running it with a debugger while such controller is connected and then looking at the stack trace could be a first hint. This would require the dev to look at the issue to have such troublesome controller (which I'm not).

There are two solutions to that issue:
1. Don't open all controllers at startup: This would prevent Citra from crashing but Citra would crash when someone tries to configure such controller.

2. Figure out the main reason why SDL crashes and upstream the fix to SDL

title: Additional display options for Stereoscopic 3D
body:
Some of this is discussed in the original pull request #3632, but I thought it'd be better to open a new issue and list the settings I think are missing.

### Option to switch left and right images
This will make it possible to see 3D using the [cross-eyed method](http://www.vision3d.com/3views.html). Currently, the image intended for the left eye is shown on the left side of the screen, and the right eye one on the right. The cross-eyed method requires them to be reversed.

### Option to disable squashing/stretching
The current output is currently squashed to half its width, which is how 3D monitors and TVs often expect to get a side-by-side 3D image. However, again, this is bad for the cross-eyed method and even the parallel method, as both methods depend on having two natural-looking images side by side.

### Different 3D output options
The following methods (see also: http://www.stereo3d.com/formats.htm and Wikipedia links below) are used by various different 3D display technologies:
1. Side by side (only method currently implemented in Citra)
2. Top and bottom - for many passive 3D displays, this would result in no data loss, while side by side has 50% of the pixels discarded by the monitor.
3. Line interlacing - odd lines are left image & even lines are right image, or vice versa. Used by many passive 3D displays.
4. [Column interlacing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax_barrier) - I'm not sure if this is actually used by any technology on the market (other than the 3DS itself!), but if you implement line interlacing I would think that column interlacing would be trivial to add. Better safe than sorry!
5. [Anaglyph 3D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anaglyph_3D) - red/cyan, and perhaps tweakable/selectable colors? This would definitely be the lowest priority IMO, I don't think it would be fun to play.
6. [Alternate frame sequencing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_shutter_3D_system) - every monitor refresh switches to the other eye. This is used by active shutter 3D glasses, such as Nvidia 3D. Of course, switching back and forth between the two images must be v-synced and independent of the game's framerate.

I ordered them in the order of what I think would be easiest to implement to hardest. As it always is, the frame stacking method (hardest) is probably the most important / would have the most users.

title: Performance degredation during playing sessions
body:
There have been several reports of Citra's performance degrading over time. Here, running Citra and starting a game, or restarting a game in an already open instance of Citra, will be considered a "session". In a session, after a varying amount of time (Reports have varied from immediate, to minutes, to hours after starting the session.), emulation will see a drastic reduction in performance. Regarding the build of Citra, on setups where this occurred, it occurred on every build tested, both Nightly (One that was tested being 687e3e7) and Canary ([`cfa6232`](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra-canary/commit/cfa6232) tested.).
I've gathered these testcases from the forum and Discord server:
- [Testcase 1](https://community.citra-emu.org/t/citra-was-running-well-and-then-it-suddenly-got-slow/43692?u=codingkoopa) ([@marcelomangerona](https://community.citra-emu.org/u/marcelomangerona)):
  - OS: macOS High Sierra 10.13.6
  - CPU: Intel Core i5 @ 2.5 GHz (model unspecified)
  - GPU: Radeon HD 6750M
  - Game(s) tested: [Pokémon Ultra Sun](https://citra-emu.org/game/pokemon-ultra-sun-ultra-moon/)
- [Testcase 2](https://community.citra-emu.org/t/frame-drop-random-but-constant/49668?u=codingkoopa) (also see [here](https://community.citra-emu.org/t/citra-was-running-well-and-then-it-suddenly-got-slow/43692/27?u=codingkoopa)) ([@Antonio_Di_Prisco](https://community.citra-emu.org/u/antonio_di_prisco)):
  - OS: Windows 7
  - CPU: Intel Core i7-2600 @ 3.40GHz
  - GPU: GeForce GTX 650 Ti BOOST
  - Game(s) tested: [Fantasy Life](https://citra-emu.org/game/fantasy-life/), [Super Mario 3D Land](https://citra-emu.org/game/super-mario-3d-land/), [Captain Toad: Treasure Tracker](https://citra-emu.org/game/captain-toad-treasure-tracker/) (Only reproduced on Fantasy Life)
- [Testcase 3](https://community.citra-emu.org/t/citra-was-running-well-and-then-it-suddenly-got-slow/43692/29?u=codingkoopa) ([@Rgnm14](https://community.citra-emu.org/u/rgnm14))
  - OS: Unspecified
  - CPU: Intel Core i7 (model unspecified)
  - GPU: GeForce GTX 1070 Ti
  - Game(s) tested: [The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask 3D](https://citra-emu.org/game/legend-of-zelda-majoras-mask/)
- [Testcase 4](https://community.citra-emu.org/t/low-fps-sudently/46982?u=codingkoopa) ([@Peteiro92](https://community.citra-emu.org/u/peteiro92))
  - OS: Unspecified
  - CPU: Unspecified
  - GPU: Unspecified
  - Game(s) tested: Pokémon Ultra Sun
- Testcase 5 (`KnightOfDQ#6953`)
  - OS: Windows 10 1803
  - CPU: Intel Core i7-2670QM @ 2.20GHz
  - GPU: GeForce GT 555M
  - Game(s) tested: [Bravely Default](https://citra-emu.org/game/bravely-default/)

From testcase 2, these are the microprofiles of idling and playing before the performance reduction occurs, and after:
![Microprofile of idling before performance reduction.](https://community.citra-emu.org/uploads/default/original/2X/0/0bb97da8c27d5fc640133b89b501c1bf0ccdbb62.png)
![Microprofile of playing the game in a 3D-heavy scene before performance reduction.](https://community.citra-emu.org/uploads/default/original/2X/8/83b6f6a0929821d5174900e5900e03164c2e7729.png)
![Microprofile of playing the game in a 3d-heavy scene after taking a screenshot.](https://community.citra-emu.org/uploads/default/original/2X/8/83b6f6a0929821d5174900e5900e03164c2e7729.png)
The last microprofile was created under the conditions of having just taken a screenshot, but acoording to OP, it looks the same as when the performance reduction normally occurs.

From testcase 5, these are the microprofiles of before and after the performance reduction occurs:
![Microprofiler before and after comparision.](https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/343888608442449920/490936365257588736/unknown.png)

I will be keeping this updated to fill in the unspecified fields, and add any new testcases.

title: Nightly #976 is freezing up every 5 minutes for 2+ mins
body:
1. Description:
Game freezes up - ROM screen completely gone, goes back to Citra Rom selection page/Game directories
Windows says: citra-qt.exe not responding.
If you wait for 2+ minutes it comes back briefly, then goes into another freeze later.
This gets worse over time - now the majority of time is "frozen".
Closing/Reopening program doesn't fix it.  Restarting machine didn't seem to fix it.
No other running programs (I tried killing a few background things (Dropbox, Onedrive) in case of low mem, but it doesn't seem to change the issue.
Looking at System Memory = normal, CPU spikes a bit, but then normal during the freezup
GPU spikes a little and is high - stays around 50% for the duration of the freezup. 

1. Current version (commit hash) of Citra you are using.
*Nightly #967 | HEAD-8c354ff*

1. Repro Case:
Playing Pokemon Sun - in main overworld, trying to catch pokemon, so going in and out of battles.  Just playing the game should cause the crash after 1 hour of play.

1.  System specs
Win10, i7 16GB ram, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960M

1. Graphics Debug/Crash log below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14063813/45521209-9103bf80-b7ac-11e8-882c-a7ccdd853e54.png)

title: Feature Request: More multiplayer modes

I want these modes so you can use multiplayer without clicking buttons, like on a real console (without using rooms and without any emulator specific feature enabled).

- Ethernet (just connect the cable and play)

title: Citra Nightly Update causes black screen with audio working
body:
Updated Citra Nightly earlier this evening and after the update black screen issue appeared.

**Game:** Pokemon Ultra Sun
**OS**: Windows 10
**GPU**: Intel HD Graphics 520
**CPU**: i5-6300U @ 2.40 GHz
**RAM**: 16GB

Citra Nightly #943 | HEAD-3b3b0bb (2018-09-01)


The issue occurs when "Enable Hardware Renderer" is enabled. The game loads up until the select save screen and then the graphics does not load. Audio seems to be working fine. Status bar shows 100% speed, 30FPS.

When Hardware Renderer is disabled, game loads in with both graphics and sound. However, the frame rate is extremely low. In some scenes, the speed drops drastically. Unenjoyable game experience.

- All graphics drivers and other hardware drivers are up-to-date.

title: Super Mario 3D Land crash on Linux w/ Hardware Shader turned off
body:
Operating System: Linux Mint 19
CPU: i5 750
GPU: AMD HD5870 (GL_VERSION: 4.3 (Core Profile) Mesa 18.0.5)
Citra Version 31.08.2018 master 

Citra crashes after a short while after street pass dialog if don’t press any buttons. This happens only on Linux and only with Hardware Shader disabled and only while showing prerecorded footage, so the stage selection and stages themselves work fine.
 Log: 
[citra_log.txt](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra/files/2342147/citra_log.txt)

title: Gameplay/audio desync issue in Theatrhythm Final Fantasy CC
body:
The game suffers from progressive gameplay-to-audio synchronization issues while playing any song.
It starts out fine but as the stage progresses, micro-stutters force the audio to fall back thus making it harder to hit most of the notes. Sometimes also big hiccups happen, freezing the game for a good 0.5 seconds (visible in the clip provided below).

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gDuRbvjH_ko&feature=youtu.be](url)

You can see the audio starts to fall behind the gameplay at around 1:26, and a particularly big hiccup at 2:33.
Can this be avoided in any way? Is the emulator at fault or my system?

Citra build: Citra Nightly #940

Graphical settings: 
- Resolution: 4x Native
- V-Sync: disabled
- Accurate Multiplication: disabled
- Accurate Geometry Shader: disabled

Audio settings: 
- Output engine: cubeb
- Audio stretching: disabled

System specifications: 
- CPU: Ryzen 3 1200
- GPU: GTX 1050Ti
- RAM: 8 GB DDR4 2667MHz
- OS: Windows 10 64-bit

title: Gamepad input - triggers registering in reverse
body:

  - For crashes, a backtrace.
  - For graphical issues, comparison screenshots with real hardware.
  - For emulation inaccuracies, a test-case (if able).

--->

Citra Nightly #937 (MacOS 10.13.6). 

Currently when registering a gamepad (tested with both bluetooth xbox controller -wireless (in built os driver) and non bluetooth controller - xbox 360/xbone driver and tested wired) both register LR shoulder buttons in reverse eg (bluetooth one) it registers as Joystick 0 axis 4- (or joystick 0 axis 5- for the other trigger) rather than what should probably be Joystick 0 axis 4. 
(tested with majora's mask).

title: Citra and Steam Link - halve game speed and FPS when Citra is active window
body:
This issue was first discussed on the Citra forum: `(https://community.citra-emu.org/t/citra-and-steam-link-halve-game-speed-and-fps-when-citra-is-active-window/44602)`

I would greatly appreciate it if someone could help out and or offer some insight or a work around.

**Issue:**

Hello! Been trying to get Citra working over steam link, but I’m running into a mighty odd problem. I went through both the Citra forum and the steam forum but to no avail. The symptom, as best I can describe is, is as followed:

It looks like Citra is being forced to run at half its speed when using steam link and while it’s the active window, it shows ~50% ~15 FPS in the bottom right corner and ~30 FPS on TV. I say “Citra as active window”, because when I change the active window on the desktop PC, or simply open the windows start menu, it goes nicely up to ~100% and ~30 FPS and the TV goes to ~ 60FPS.

What is especially odd to look at is to open task manager on the CPU usage and switch between the Citra window and Task manager and see the FPS shift. At 100% game speed there is around 60% CPU usage, when Citra is the active window and the game goes to 50%, the CPU usage is about 35%.

Some things that I have tried, but did not help:

-  Run Citra outside of steam link, games work fine, controller works fine.
- Configured Citra as non steam game, directly opening the game
- Tried two different games Zelda MM and Zelda LBW, both have this issue
- Other non steam games work find through Steam link (played Talos Principle and CEMU Zelda BOTW), appear normal/OK
- Disconnected second monitor
- Updated AMD drivers, tried 18.5.1 and 18.8.1 (latest)
- Tried both regular and beta steam clients
- Tried running games uncapped at 200%, desktop only, the games go to about 150-170%, trough steam link, fastest is ~50%
- Making a different window active, makes game run normal speed 100% 30 FPS, 60 FPS on steam link
- V-sync is off in Citra and AMD global settings
- Killed Steam link on the television, while still running on the desktop, when setting Citra as the active window, the speed remains at 100% and 30 FPS. When reconnecting the stream (apparently that’s possible) the problem returns.
- Tried other various settings for max speed performance etc. I read a Steam link forum post about steam link capping a program when it notices it runs at low FPS at first or somewhere during play.
-  Tried setting CPU affinity for Citra to 0-3 and Steam to 4 - 7, no effect
- Set desktop PC power plan to ‘High Performance’
- The steam link encoding threads was set to automatic. I set it to 1, restarted everything, but no improvement…
- I originally started out with the Steam Link on software encoding, but switched on the setting for hardware encoding with my AMD graphics card. Also to no effect… 

As a workaround I have been looking in to setting a different active window and try playing, however the controller then controls the mouse and you can, for example, scroll down pages in an internet browser… but not actually play the game.

**System Information**

    Operating System: Windows 10 Pro, recently updated
    CPU: Intel Core i7 960 @ 3.2 Ghz
    GPU: AMD Radeon R9 380
    Citra Version (found in title bar): Nightly #925 (latest)
    Game: Zelda MM, Zelda LBW, Zelda OoT

**Screenshot of Issue**

Citra as active window, Steam link on, screenshot of Desktop:

![citra-active-window-steam-link-on](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14330834/44631879-9d95b480-a972-11e8-9aa0-07696a76d2d7.png)

Task manager as active window, Steam link on, screenshot of Desktop, showing CPU usage after switching active windows back and forth.

![citra-toggle-window-steam-link-on-cpu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14330834/44631882-a71f1c80-a972-11e8-84e4-afcf18963233.png)

Citra as active window, Steam link on, photo of TV:

![img_20180826_115005](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14330834/44631894-d0d84380-a972-11e8-9155-910abbea66dd.jpg)

The steam menu, running normal at 60 FPS.

![img_20180826_114923](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14330834/44631885-b736fc00-a972-11e8-9779-9fe7a79055c4.jpg)

Citra running the game at 100%, 30 FPS, Steam link at 60 FPS when task manager is the active window:

![img_20180826_115529](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14330834/44631899-dcc40580-a972-11e8-8bdb-503ce8c3d81d.jpg)

**Logs**

[streaming_log.txt](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra/files/2321805/streaming_log.txt)
